elements.content: Three lanthanide-thiophenedicarboxylate hybrid compounds, [(Eu2(TDC)3(CH3OH)2·(CH3OH)] (1), [(Yb2(TDC)3(DMF)(H2O)·(CH3CH2OH)] (2), and [(Tb2(TDC)3(H2O)4] (3) (where TDC is deprotonated thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid and DMF is dimethylformamide), have been prepared by a hydrothermal method. The TDC ligands exhibit two unprecedented (κ2-κ1-μ2)−(κ1-κ1)−μ5 and (κ2)−(κ2)−μ2 coordination modes as well as other various modes. Structure analysis reveals that 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid play a versatile role toward different lanthanide ions to form three-dimensional inorganic−organic hybrid frameworks. The luminescence experiments show that Eu(III) and Tb(III) compounds exhibit typical luminescence in the visible region, while the Yb(III) compound emits characteristic near-infrared luminescence in the solid state even with the coordinated water molecules. Besides luminescence, the Tb(III) compound also shows weak ferromagnetic behavior, which indicates that it is acting as a dual function material.

Besides luminescence, the Tb(III) compound also shows weak ferromagnetic behavior, which indicates that it is acting as a dual function material.

elements.content: Lanthanide-thiophenedicarboxylate hybrid compounds were prepared by a hydrothermal method using 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (TDC) as one of the assembly origins. The TDC ligands exhibit two unprecedented coordination modes and play a versatile role toward different lanthanide ions forming three-dimensional inorganic−organic hybrid frameworks. These new inorganic−organic hybrid materials exhibit intense luminescence in the visible and near-infrared regions as well as ferromagnetic properties.
elements.clean_text: Lanthanide-thiophenedicarboxylate hybrid compounds were prepared by a hydrothermal method using 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (TDC) as one of the assembly origins. The TDC ligands exhibit two unprecedented coordination modes and play a versatile role toward different lanthanide ions forming three-dimensional inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks. These new inorganic-organic hybrid materials exhibit intense luminescence in the visible and near-infrared regions as well as ferromagnetic properties.

elements.content: In recent years, the design and synthesis of novel organic−inorganic hybrid materials have provoked significant interest owing to their enormous variety of intriguing structural topologies and their fascinating properties as well as great potential applications as microporous, magnetic, nonlinear optical, and fluorescent materials. These kinds of materials take advantage of the best properties of organic and inorganic components that form the hybrid and decrease or eliminate their drawbacks achieving in an ideal way a synergic effect. Among them, lanthanide−organic hybrid materials have recently been a rapidly developing area because their unique luminescence properties are advantageous in applications such as fluoroimmuno-assays, light-emitting diodes, laser systems, and optical amplification for telecommunications as well as magnetic materials. For example, the intense, long-lived, and line-like emission of lanthanides such as Eu(III) and Tb(III) in the visible region has made them of widespread interest for a range of applications from biological assays to display devices. In contrast, the longer wavelength emission of lanthanides such as Yb(III), Nd(III), Dy(III), Pr(III), and Er(III) in the near-infrared (NIR) region has been less well studied, although this situation is being remedied. Recent interest in the photophysical properties of these lanthanide ions stems from their possible use in medical diagnostics, because the longer emission wavelengths (and hence, possibly, longer excitation wavelengths) penetrate human tissue far more effectively than does UV or visible light. NIR luminescence from metals such as Dy(III), Nd(III), and Er(III) is used as the basis for the optical amplifiers. In addition, the large unquenched orbital angular momentum of most of lanthanide(III) ions associated with the internal nature of the valence f orbitals makes such ions very appealing for the preparation of magnetic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the design and synthesis of novel organic-inorganic hybrid materials have provoked significant interest owing to their enormous variety of intriguing structural topologies and their fascinating properties as well as great potential applications as microporous, magnetic, nonlinear optical, and fluorescent materials. These kinds of materials take advantage of the best properties of organic and inorganic components that form the hybrid and decrease or eliminate their drawbacks achieving in an ideal way a synergic effect. Among them, lanthanide-organic hybrid materials have recently been a rapidly developing area because their unique luminescence properties are advantageous in applications such as fluoroimmuno-assays, light-emitting diodes, laser systems, and optical amplification for telecommunications as well as magnetic materials. For example, the intense, long-lived, and line-like emission of lanthanides such as Eu(III) and Tb(III) in the visible region has made them of widespread interest for a range of applications from biological assays to display devices. In contrast, the longer wavelength emission of lanthanides such as Yb(III), Nd(III), Dy(III), Pr(III), and Er(III) in the near-infrared (NIR) region has been less well studied, although this situation is being remedied. Recent interest in the photophysical properties of these lanthanide ions stems from their possible use in medical diagnostics, because the longer emission wavelengths (and hence, possibly, longer excitation wavelengths) penetrate human tissue far more effectively than does UV or visible light. NIR luminescence from metals such as Dy(III), Nd(III), and Er(III) is used as the basis for the optical amplifiers. In addition, the large unquenched orbital angular momentum of most of lanthanide(III) ions associated with the internal nature of the valence f orbitals makes such ions very appealing for the preparation of magnetic materials.

elements.content: However, lanthanide ions are very poor at absorbing light directly, because of the low extinction coefficients of the Laporte forbidden f−f transitions; energy transfer from an adjacent strongly absorbing chromophore is usually used to stimulate luminescence from lanthanides. In this regard, the ligands with good light absorptivity and strong coordination capability to lanthanide ions should be selected as building units for lanthanide-organic hybrid. To this end, carboxylic acids have been selected as building units, given that lanthanide ions have a high affinity for hard donor atoms and ligands containing oxygen atoms, which are frequently employed in the construction of transition metal or lanthanide-containing coordination polymers. For sensitizing groups, we find that conjugated organic polymers such as polythiophenes are natural semiconductors with tunable band gaps finding applications in the production of transistors, photovoltaics, photomagnetic materials, and light-emitting diodes. The introduction of metal ions into organic polymers offers potential in the area of inorganic−organic hybrid materials either by attaching metals to the polymer as an electronically coupled appendage or incorporating them within the backbone. As a logical starting point of this project, we choose thiophene-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (H2TDC) as a sensitizing chromophore and multicarboxylate linker to incorporate lanthanide ions into the hybrid materials. Because of the big radius of the S atom, its lone pair of electrons can be more easily delocalized within the heterocycle, and the ligand exhibits good charge-transfer ability. In the industry, H2TDC is an important intermediate in the preparation of fluorescent brightening agents. Therefore, it is expected that a hybrid lanthanide-H2TDC compound would exhibit interesting photoluminescent, magnetic, and/or sensor properties. From a structural point of view, H2TDC seems to be a promising organic linker because two carboxyl groups with a “V-shaped” configuration are able to establish bridges between several metal centers through various coordination modes (Scheme ) found in a large number of coordination polymers made up of transition metals and H2TDC. Compared with transition metals, the analogous lanthanide compounds are not yet well developed. Herein, we report a series of three-dimensional lanthanide−TDC hybrid materials: [(Eu2(TDC)3(CH3OH)2·(CH3OH)] (1), [(Yb2(TDC)3(DMF)(H2O)·(CH3CH2OH)] (2), and [(Tb2(TDC)3(H2O)4] (3), of which crystal structures, thermal stabilities, magnetic, and luminescent properties have also been investigated.

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and were used without further purification. Lanthanide chloride salts were prepared by dissolving lanthanide oxides with concentrated HCl, and then evaporating at 100 °C until the crystal film formed. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on an AB-Series 2 luminescence spectrometer. The elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in 400−4000 cm−1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were undertaken on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer from 2 to 300 K. Data was corrected for the diamagnetic contribution calculated from Pascal constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade or better and were used without further purification. Lanthanide chloride salts were prepared by dissolving lanthanide oxides with concentrated HCl, and then evaporating at 100 °C until the crystal film formed. Fluorescence spectroscopy data were recorded on an AB-Series 2 luminescence spectrometer. The elemental analyses were carried out on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in 400-4000 cm-1 region on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C/min using a Perkin-Elmer TGA 7 thermogravimetric analyzer. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were undertaken on a Quantum Design MPMS-XL7 SQUID magnetometer from 2 to 300 K. Data was corrected for the diamagnetic contribution calculated from Pascal constants.

elements.content: Data collection was performed on a SIEMENS SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically (C−H bond fixed at 0.99 Å) and refined using riding mode. Crystallographic data and structure determination summaries are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallographic Study

Data collection was performed on a SIEMENS SMART CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at room temperature. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The positions of hydrogen atoms attached to carbon atoms were generated geometrically (C-H bond fixed at 0.99 Å) and refined using riding mode. Crystallographic data and structure determination summaries are listed in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table .

This compound was synthesized solvothermally, by reacting H2TDC and EuCl3 ·6H2O in a molar ratio of 1:1 in the presence of 5 mL of CH3OH for two days at 120 °C and then cooled for 12 h. The final product obtained as colorless cubic crystals was collected by filtration and washed with CH3OH. Yield: 30% (based on europium). Anal. Calcd. for C21H15O16S3Eu2: C, 27.31; H, 1.64%. Found: C, 26.21; H, 1.94%.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that compounds 1 and 2 have very similar structures and crystallize in the same monoclinic space group P2(1)/n both exhibiting three-dimensional frameworks. As a representative example, the crystal structure of compound 1 is described here in detail.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structures of [(Eu2(TDC)3(CH3OH)2⋅(CH3OH)] (1) and [(Yb2(TDC)3(DMF)(H2O)⋅(CH3CH2OH)] (2)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies reveal that compounds 1 and 2 have very similar structures and crystallize in the same monoclinic space group P2(1)/n both exhibiting three-dimensional frameworks. As a representative example, the crystal structure of compound 1 is described here in detail.

elements.content: Each asymmetric unit [(Eu2(TDC)3(CH3OH)2·(CH3OH)] contains two europium ions, three TDC ligands, two coordinated CH3OH molecules, and one uncoordinated CH3OH molecule (Figure ). There are two independent Eu ions. Eu1 is coordinated with eight oxygen atoms from one chelating bidentate carboxyl group (O7C and O8C), five dimonodentate carboxyl groups (O1A, O2D, O4, O7B, and O12E), and one terminal CH3OH molecule (O14). The eight oxygen atoms coordinated with Eu2 are from six dimonodentate carboxyl groups (O3, O5, O6, O9F, O10, and O11E) and two oxygen atoms (O13 and O15) of two terminal CH3OH molecules. The O−Eu bonds are in the range of 2.266(8)−2.651(6) Å, all of which are comparable to those reported for other europium−oxygen donor compounds except for a weakly coordinated band Eu2−O15 with a distance of ca. 2.85 Å (Figure a). Figure b shows the bonding models of the bridging ligand TDC displaying in structures. Apart from the (κ1-κ1)−(κ1-κ1)−μ4 bis-bidentate coordination mode, the TDC in compound 1 also exhibits a unique (κ2-κ1-μ2)−(κ1-κ1)−μ5 pentadentate coordination mode which is different from those found in previous work (Scheme ).

elements.content: As shown in Figure , a lanthanide metal center atom (Eu1) and its corresponding centro-symmetric atom Eu1J (symmetry J: −x, 2 − y, −1 − z) are linked together through four chelating/bridging bidentate carboxyl groups of TDC ligands to form an edge-sharing metallic dimer with a metal···metal distance about 3.95 Å. Similarly, Eu2 and Eu2F are bridged by two bidentate carboxyl groups and two tridentate carboxylate from four TDC linkers to form another centrosymmetric dimer with Eu2···Eu2F separation of 4.27 Å. Furthermore, these two Eu2 dimers are connected to each other by two bidentate carboxyl groups (Eu1···Eu2 5.32 Å) resulting in the formation of a Eu4O32 building unit (bottom-left in Figure ), which extend out repeatedly along an axis leading to the formation of a one-dimensional inorganic chain as shown in the top of Figure . These inorganic chains are bridged through aromatic TDC ligands within the crystallographic bc plane forming ca. 5 × 10 Å2 rhombic channels along the a direction (Figure ). A PLATON program analysis suggests that approximately 8% of the crystal volume is accessible to the solvents. When the lattice free methanol molecules are removed, the volume increases up to 28.4%. These neutral channels could provide very likely potentials for recognizing and sensing some small molecules. Compound 2 has a very similar structure with compound 1 other than displacing two ethanol molecules by one water and one DMF molecule (Figure ).

elements.content: The X-ray analysis reveals that each asymmetric unit [(Tb2(TDC)3(H2O)4] is composed of one Tb(III) ion, one and a half TDC ligands, and two coordinated water molecules (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, each Tb(III) ion is eight coordinated with eight oxygen atoms from two water molecules (O1w and O2w), four bidentate carboxyl groups (O1, O2, O3, and O4), and one chelating bidentate carboxyl group (O5 and O6). TDC ligands take one new coordination mode (κ2)−(κ2)−μ2 (Scheme ) and a (κ1-κ1)−(κ1-κ1)−μ4 mode to bridge Tb(III) ions (Figure c). Two symmetry-related Tb(III) ions are connected via the bidentate carboxylate of TDC ligands. And three neighbor Tb(III) ions are bridged by three carboxylate groups to form a triangular arrangement, which is extended with shared edges, thereby forming a one-dimensional (1D) lanthanide inorganic chain along the crystallographic b axis (top in Figure ). These 1D chains are further connected by aromatic TDC linkers and expand in crystallographic a- and c-axes to form a 3-D framework with three interpenetrated channels along the three crystallographic axes (Figure ). There are large cross-linking trapezoidal channels parallel to the crystallographic c axis with dimensions of ca. 18.8 × 5.5 Å2. Interestingly, the structures of 1−3 are different from that of MOF-75 (Tb(TDC)(NO3)(DMF)2) previously prepared by a different procedure. Because of the coordination of NO3 − to Tb3+, the ratio of TDC/Tb is less than that of compound 3. Increasing the composition of TDC in the crystals would benefit efficiently sensing the light for the hybrid to yield stronger luminescence. Structurally, in MOF-75, the carboxyl groups are all coordinated according to a (κ1-κ1)−(κ1-κ1)−μ4 mode, which could bond fewer lanthanide ions.

The X-ray analysis reveals that each asymmetric unit [(Tb2(TDC)3(H2O)4] is composed of one Tb(III) ion, one and a half TDC ligands, and two coordinated water molecules (Figure a). As shown in Figure b, each Tb(III) ion is eight coordinated with eight oxygen atoms from two water molecules (O1w and O2w), four bidentate carboxyl groups (O1, O2, O3, and O4), and one chelating bidentate carboxyl group (O5 and O6). TDC ligands take one new coordination mode (κ2)-(κ2)-μ2 (Scheme ) and a (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 mode to bridge Tb(III) ions (Figure c). Two symmetry-related Tb(III) ions are connected via the bidentate carboxylate of TDC ligands. And three neighbor Tb(III) ions are bridged by three carboxylate groups to form a triangular arrangement, which is extended with shared edges, thereby forming a one-dimensional (1D) lanthanide inorganic chain along the crystallographic b axis (top in Figure ). These 1D chains are further connected by aromatic TDC linkers and expand in crystallographic a- and c-axes to form a 3-D framework with three interpenetrated channels along the three crystallographic axes (Figure ). There are large cross-linking trapezoidal channels parallel to the crystallographic c axis with dimensions of ca. 18.8 × 5.5 Å2. Interestingly, the structures of 1-3 are different from that of MOF-75 (Tb(TDC)(NO3)(DMF)2) previously prepared by a different procedure. Because of the coordination of NO3 - to Tb3+, the ratio of TDC/Tb is less than that of compound 3. Increasing the composition of TDC in the crystals would benefit efficiently sensing the light for the hybrid to yield stronger luminescence. Structurally, in MOF-75, the carboxyl groups are all coordinated according to a (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 mode, which could bond fewer lanthanide ions.

Thermal Stability of Compounds 1-3   

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1-3 have been determined by using TGA. All of the TGA curves (Figure ) show the first weight losses of solvent molecules. The total observed weight losses (ca. 10 %) are in a good agreement with the calculated values (10.4, 12.5, and 8.0%), which are based on the removal of one free CH3OH molecule and two coordinated CH3OH molecules from 1; one coordinated DMF, one coordinated water and one free ethanol molecule from 2; four coordinated water molecules from 3, respectively.

elements.content: It has been known that the lanthanide-centered emission can be sensitized by some selected organic molecules with π-systems. Because of the low molar absorptivity of the lanthanide ions in nature, direct excitation only produces weak emission spectra. When the metals are compounded or chelated with organic moieties that can efficiently absorb and transfer the energy, significantly enhanced emission can be generated. Generally, direct excitation of the ligand to a singlet excited-state followed by an intersystem crossing (ISC) to a triplet excited-state with the emission from the metal results when a nonradiative energy transfer occurs from the ligand triplet state to the lanthanide ion center. This effect is commonly known as the “antenna effect”. Because of the high effective bonding modes, high composition of sensitizing groups and the appropriate energy level of the ligand, it is believed that the thiophene-carboxylate ligand could act as a good sensitizer for the central lanthanide ion.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

It has been known that the lanthanide-centered emission can be sensitized by some selected organic molecules with π-systems. Because of the low molar absorptivity of the lanthanide ions in nature, direct excitation only produces weak emission spectra. When the metals are compounded or chelated with organic moieties that can efficiently absorb and transfer the energy, significantly enhanced emission can be generated. Generally, direct excitation of the ligand to a singlet excited-state followed by an intersystem crossing (ISC) to a triplet excited-state with the emission from the metal results when a nonradiative energy transfer occurs from the ligand triplet state to the lanthanide ion center. This effect is commonly known as the "antenna effect". Because of the high effective bonding modes, high composition of sensitizing groups and the appropriate energy level of the ligand, it is believed that the thiophene-carboxylate ligand could act as a good sensitizer for the central lanthanide ion.

elements.content: The emission spectra obtained for the compounds 1−3 in the solid state have been done with excitation wavelength at 395, 310, and 330 nm, respectively. The spectrum of the Eu compound 1 (top of Figure ) shows a weak band observed in the region of the 5D0 → 7F0 transition. 5D0 → 7F1 is the second intense transition; it consists of a single peak without any splitting. The hypersensitive transition, 5D0 → 7F2, is the most intense transition and consists of an intense band with one weak shoulder at lower frequency. A less intense broad peak is observed for the 5D0 → 7F3 transition, while the 5D0 → 7F4 transition comprised of two peaks with not well-defined character. For europium(III), the splitting of the ground-state levels can be readily predicted from group theory and allow for the local site symmetry of the compound to be determined. When Eu3+ cations exist in a D 4 site symmetry, two components for the 5D0 → 7F1 transition and one component of the 5D0 → 7F2 transition are expected to be observed while the 5D0 → 7F0 transitions remain strongly forbidden. In fact, compound 1 shows that only one peak is observed for the 5D0 → 7F1 transition, one moderate shoulder is seen on the hypersensitive 5D0 → 7F2 transition indicating a heavy distortion from an ideal D 4 symmetry. The observed 5D0 → 7F3 and 5D0 → 7F5 transitions also did not show distinct two peaks expected for an ideal D 4 symmetric Eu(III) ion. Hence, based on the spectroscopic data collected, it is indicated that compound 1 contains heavily distorted square antiprismatic geometric metal cations in a D 4d point symmetry, which is in agreement with the results from the X-ray structure analysis.

elements.content: As exhibited in middle panel of Figure , compound 2 gives typical Yb(III) centered near-infrared luminescence at 980 nm. Ytterbium(III) is a special case among the near-infrared-emitting lanthanide ions, because the Yb(III) ion has only one excited 4f level, namely, the 2F5/2 level. So its luminescence observed at 980 nm is assigned to the 5F5/2 → 2F7/2 transition. Even though the present Yb(III) compound contains a number of solvent molecules directly coordinated to lanthanide ions, the near-IR emission of Yb compound is still moderately intense which is weakened by vibration excitation of C−H or O−H bonds due to effective radiation-less transitions.

elements.content: The spectrum collected for the terbium(III) compound 3 (bottom of Figure ) is impressive as all the transitions to the ground-state manifold from the emitting 5D4 level are observed in detail. The 5D4 → 7F6 is the second strongest peak observed without any splitting. Similar to the europium spectra, the dominant peak corresponding to 5D4 → 7F5 transition is the hypersensitive, which is made up of a single intense peak with a second shoulder at slightly lower frequency. The 5D4 → 7F4 and 5D4 → 7F2 transitions consist of two peaks of equal intensity. Finally, there is a weak shoulder followed by a second intense peak at lower frequency for the 5D4 → 7F3 transition while the 5D4 → 7F1 and 5D4 → 7F0 transitions are single peaks with weak but measurable intensities.

elements.content: The mechanism of energy transfer from ligands to metal ions has been widely discussed to interpret the luminescence of lanthanide compounds. When the triplet state energy of the ligand is greater than or equal to the energy gap between the excited-state and ground-state of the metal ions, efficient luminescence could be obtained. From the results discussed above, we could presume that the energy gaps of the lanthanide ions are comparable with the triplet state energy of the thiophene-carboxylate ligand, which make these compounds potential fluorescent materials. On the other hand, the design and synthesis of new multifunction molecular materials started with a novel system having both conductivity and ferromagnetic property, which continue to elicit great interest from chemists in a variety of disciplines. In this regard, we have investigated the magnetic properties of the Tb(III) compound that might display a dual function behavior on luminescence and magnetism.

When the triplet state energy of the ligand is greater than or equal to the energy gap between the excited-state and ground-state of the metal ions, efficient luminescence could be obtained. From the results discussed above, we could presume that the energy gaps of the lanthanide ions are comparable with the triplet state energy of the thiophene-carboxylate ligand, which make these compounds potential fluorescent materials. On the other hand, the design and synthesis of new multifunction molecular materials started with a novel system having both conductivity and ferromagnetic property, which continue to elicit great interest from chemists in a variety of disciplines. In this regard, we have investigated the magnetic properties of the Tb(III) compound that might display a dual function behavior on luminescence and magnetism.

elements.content: It is well-known that for systems containing Ln(III) ions the effects of the magnetic exchange coupling are much weaker than those of transition-metal ions because the f orbitals are well shielded by outer s and p orbitals and less extended than d orbitals of transition-metal ions. In most of cases, analysis of the magnetic interaction between rare-earth ions gives rise to additional difficulties since the magnitude of these interactions is comparable with that of the crystal field acting on the ion due to the large orbital contribution. Additionally, the carboxylate groups can adopt a variety of bridging modes as shown in Scheme . They can link two or more metal ions and mediate ferro- or antiferromagnetic coupling between the metal ions in different situations. According to the structure described above, in compound 3, three Tb(III) ions are bridged by three syn-syn carboxylate groups forming a triangle arrangement and the Tb3 unit repeat them infinitely by sharing edges. Thus it is interesting to perform magnetic studies evaluating the eventual exchange interactions between the terbium(III) centers as the concomitant function of this luminescence hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties of Compound 3 

It is well-known that for systems containing Ln(III) ions the effects of the magnetic exchange coupling are much weaker than those of transition-metal ions because the f orbitals are well shielded by outer s and p orbitals and less extended than d orbitals of transition-metal ions. In most of cases, analysis of the magnetic interaction between rare-earth ions gives rise to additional difficulties since the magnitude of these interactions is comparable with that of the crystal field acting on the ion due to the large orbital contribution. Additionally, the carboxylate groups can adopt a variety of bridging modes as shown in Scheme . They can link two or more metal ions and mediate ferro- or antiferromagnetic coupling between the metal ions in different situations. According to the structure described above, in compound 3, three Tb(III) ions are bridged by three syn-syn carboxylate groups forming a triangle arrangement and the Tb3 unit repeat them infinitely by sharing edges. Thus it is interesting to perform magnetic studies evaluating the eventual exchange interactions between the terbium(III) centers as the concomitant function of this luminescence hybrid materials.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compound 3 have been measured for a polycrystalline sample at an applied magnetic field of 5000 Oe in the temperature range of 2−300 K. For compound 3 (Figure ), the observed value of χM T per [Tb] unit is 13.32 emu K mol−1 at room temperature, which is slightly larger than the value (11.82 emu K mol−1) of a free Tb3+ ion in the 7F6 state. As the temperature decreased to ca. 14 K, χM T increased smoothly with a following decrease. The plot of χM −1 vs. T over the whole temperature range obeys the Curie−Weiss law [χM = C/(T − θ)] with C = 13.37 emu K mol−1 and θ = 1.68 K. The increase of χM T within the higher temperature range coupled with the positive θ indicates a weak ferromagnetic coupling between Tb3+ ions. The ferromagnetic interaction is also confirmed by the isothermal magnetization at 5 K, which increases rapidly and saturates with the field up to 2 T.

elements.content: The ac susceptibility measurements were performed on a sample of compound 3 in a 3 Oe ac field oscillating at 1−1488 Hz with a zero applied dc field (Figure ). Although the χM′ vs. T plot shows no obvious frequency dependence above 1.8 K, the out-of-phase magnetic susceptibility (χM′′) signals shows nonzero and a rather smaller frequency dependence. It appears to be paramagnetic with very weak ferromagnetic coupling. Unfortunately, there is no maximum for the χM′′ signals down to 1.8 K. Although it is not clear what is the origin of this phenomenon in the case, further magnetic measurements at lower temperature so as to get the shift of peak temperature (T p) of χM′′ by a parameter φ (φ = ΔT p/[T pΔ(log f)]) should be performed to discuss the problem.

elements.content: In conclusion, the synthesis and characterization of three lanthanide-thiophenedicarboxylate hybrid compounds were performed by a hydrothermal method. The TDC ligands exhibit two unprecedented coordination modes (κ2-κ1-μ2)−(κ1-κ1)−μ5 and (κ2)−(κ2)−μ2 in these compounds and play a versatile role toward different lanthanide ions to form 3-D inorganic−organic hybrid frameworks. The studies of luminescence properties show that Eu(III) and Tb(III) compounds exhibited typical intense luminescence in the visible region; the Yb(III) compound emit moderate characteristic near-infrared luminescence in solid state even with coordinated solvents. Magnetic studies reveal that the ferromagnetic interactions appear in the Tb(III) compound, which could be seen as a dual function materials. Research along this line for development of more interesting new inorganic−organic hybrid layered and porous luminescence materials by expanding the polythiophene conjugated ligands is underway in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, the synthesis and characterization of three lanthanide-thiophenedicarboxylate hybrid compounds were performed by a hydrothermal method. The TDC ligands exhibit two unprecedented coordination modes (κ2-κ1-μ2)-(κ1-κ1)-μ5 and (κ2)-(κ2)-μ2 in these compounds and play a versatile role toward different lanthanide ions to form 3-D inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks. The studies of luminescence properties show that Eu(III) and Tb(III) compounds exhibited typical intense luminescence in the visible region; the Yb(III) compound emit moderate characteristic near-infrared luminescence in solid state even with coordinated solvents. Magnetic studies reveal that the ferromagnetic interactions appear in the Tb(III) compound, which could be seen as a dual function materials. Research along this line for development of more interesting new inorganic-organic hybrid layered and porous luminescence materials by expanding the polythiophene conjugated ligands is underway in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content:
This compound was synthesized solvothermally, by reacting H2TDC and EuCl3 ·6H2O in a molar ratio of 1:1 in the presence of 5 mL of CH3OH for two days at 120 °C and then cooled for 12 h. The final product obtained as colorless cubic crystals was collected by filtration and washed with CH3OH. Yield: 30% (based on europium). Anal. Calcd. for C21H15O16S3Eu2: C, 27.31; H, 1.64%. Found: C, 26.21; H, 1.94%.

Synthesis of [(Yb<sub>2</sub>(TDC)<sub>3</sub>(DMF)(H<sub>2</sub>O)·(CH<sub>3</sub>CH<sub>2</sub>OH)] (<bold>2</bold>)

This compound was synthesized solvothermally, by reacting H2TDC and YbCl3·6H2O in a molar ratio of 1:1 in the presence of 5 mL of DMF, 1 mL of CH3CH2OH, and 1 mL of H2O for three days at 60 °C and then cooled for 12 h. The final product obtained as colorless cubic crystals was collected by filtration and washed with CH3OH. Yield: 35% (based on ytterbium). Anal. Calcd for C23H21N1O15S3Yb2: C, 27.8; H, 2.13; N, 1.41%. Found: C, 28.5; H, 2.41; N, 1.05%.

Synthesis of [(Tb<sub>2</sub>(TDC)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>] (<bold>3</bold>)

This compound was synthesized solvothermally, by reacting H2TDC and TbCl3·6H2O in a molar ratio of 1:1 in the presence of 7 mL of CH3OH for two days at 120 °C and then cooled for 12 h. The final product obtained as colorless crystals was collected by filtration and washed with CH3OH. Yield: 25% (based on terbium). Anal. Calcd. for C18H14O16S3Tb2: C, 24.01; H, 1.57%. Found: C, 23.46; H, 2.01%.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stabilities of compounds 1−3 have been determined by using TGA. All of the TGA curves (Figure ) show the first weight losses of solvent molecules. The total observed weight losses (ca. 10 %) are in a good agreement with the calculated values (10.4, 12.5, and 8.0%), which are based on the removal of one free CH3OH molecule and two coordinated CH3OH molecules from 1; one coordinated DMF, one coordinated water and one free ethanol molecule from 2; four coordinated water molecules from 3, respectively.

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compound 3 have been measured for a polycrystalline sample at an applied magnetic field of 5000 Oe in the temperature range of 2−300 K. For compound 3 (Figure ), the observed value of χM T per [Tb] unit is 13.32 emu K mol−1 at room temperature, which is slightly larger than the value (11.82 emu K mol−1) of a free Tb3+ ion in the 7F6 state. As the temperature decreased to ca. 14 K, χM T increased smoothly with a following decrease. The plot of χM −1 vs. T over the whole temperature range obeys the Curie−Weiss law [χM = C/(T − θ)] with C = 13.37 emu K mol−1 and θ = 1.68 K. The increase of χM T within the higher temperature range coupled with the positive θ indicates a weak ferromagnetic coupling between Tb3+ ions. The ferromagnetic interaction is also confirmed by the isothermal magnetization at 5 K, which increases rapidly and saturates with the field up to 2 T.

Thermal Stability of Compounds 1-3   

The thermal stabilities of compounds 1-3 have been determined by using TGA. All of the TGA curves (Figure ) show the first weight losses of solvent molecules. The total observed weight losses (ca. 10 %) are in a good agreement with the calculated values (10.4, 12.5, and 8.0%), which are based on the removal of one free CH3OH molecule and two coordinated CH3OH molecules from 1; one coordinated DMF, one coordinated water and one free ethanol molecule from 2; four coordinated water molecules from 3, respectively.

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility data of compound 3 have been measured for a polycrystalline sample at an applied magnetic field of 5000 Oe in the temperature range of 2-300 K. For compound 3 (Figure ), the observed value of χM T per [Tb] unit is 13.32 emu K mol-1 at room temperature, which is slightly larger than the value (11.82 emu K mol-1) of a free Tb3+ ion in the 7F6 state. As the temperature decreased to ca. 14 K, χM T increased smoothly with a following decrease. The plot of χM -1 vs. T over the whole temperature range obeys the Curie-Weiss law [χM = C/(T - θ)] with C = 13.37 emu K mol-1 and θ = 1.68 K. The increase of χM T within the higher temperature range coupled with the positive θ indicates a weak ferromagnetic coupling between Tb3+ ions. The ferromagnetic interaction is also confirmed by the isothermal magnetization at 5 K, which increases rapidly and saturates with the field up to 2 T.
